title: Implement R2 storage for files
description:
## Overview
Cloudflare R2 storage layer for all binary files (plan images, photos, voice notes) with signed URLs for secure access.

## Agent Assignment
@agent-backend

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] R2 bucket configured for SiteLink files
- [ ] Upload endpoint generates presigned PUT URLs
- [ ] Download uses presigned GET URLs with expiration
- [ ] Organized bucket structure by org/project/type
- [ ] CORS configured for mobile app and web access
- [ ] Storage usage tracked per organization
- [ ] Cleanup job removes orphaned files
- [ ] Max file sizes enforced: photos 10MB, PDFs 100MB, audio 5MB

## Bucket Structure
```
sitelink-files/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ orgs/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {orgId}/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ plans/
‚îÇ       ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {projectId}/
‚îÇ       ‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ sheets/
‚îÇ       ‚îÇ           ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {sheetId}.jpg
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ photos/
‚îÇ       ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {photoId}.jpg
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ audio/
‚îÇ           ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ {voiceNoteId}.m4a
```

## API Endpoints
```
POST /v1/storage/presigned-upload
Body: { type: 'photo' | 'audio' | 'plan', filename, contentType, size }
Response: { uploadUrl, fileKey, expiresAt }

POST /v1/storage/presigned-download
Body: { fileKey }
Response: { downloadUrl, expiresAt }

GET /v1/storage/usage
Response: { usedBytes, limitBytes, breakdown: { plans, photos, audio } }
```

## Example Upload Flow
```
Mobile App:
1. Capture photo locally
2. Request presigned URL: POST /v1/storage/presigned-upload
3. Receive: { uploadUrl: "https://...", fileKey: "orgs/x/photos/y.jpg" }
4. PUT file directly to R2 via uploadUrl
5. On success, commit photoUploaded event with remotePath = fileKey
```

## Design Notes
- Use R2 bindings in Cloudflare Workers
- Presigned URLs expire in 1 hour for uploads, 24 hours for downloads
- Track uploads in D1 for usage calculation
- Background job to reconcile storage vs database
- Consider R2 lifecycle rules for cleanup

title: Set up local callout processor testing workflow
description:
## Context

This is a **blocking prerequisite** for fixing callout marker positions (sitelink-0zx).

Currently, the `sitelink_backend-dev/packages/callout-processor` has a standalone CLI that allows:
```bash
# From README.md
bun run src/index.ts detect --pdf ./test.pdf --output ./output
```

But the main sitelink repo has NO equivalent. All processing goes through the full backend ‚Üí container ‚Üí queue pipeline, making it impossible to:
1. Quickly test detection on a PDF
2. Generate debug/annotated images locally
3. Compare detection results with mobile rendering
4. Iterate on coordinate transformations

---

## Requirements

### Must Have
1. **CLI command** to process a PDF and output:
   - Annotated debug image (like `callouts_annotated.png`)
   - JSON with detected markers and normalized coordinates
   - Sheet metadata (dimensions, rotation applied)

2. **Matching settings** with production:
   - Same DPI (300)
   - Same rotation handling (apply PDF /Rotate)
   - Same coordinate normalization

3. **PMTiles generation** option:
   - Generate tiles from the same image
   - Allow visual verification of marker positioning

### Nice to Have
1. **Side-by-side comparison tool** - show mobile screenshot vs debug image
2. **Coordinate calculator** - input normalized coords, show pixel positions

---

## Approach Options

### Option A: Port to monorepo (Recommended)
Create `packages/callout-processor/` in main sitelink repo:
- Port code from `sitelink_backend-dev/packages/callout-processor`
- Ensure it uses same detection logic as `apps/backend/container/server.py`
- Add as workspace package for import by backend

**Pros:**
- Single source of truth
- Easy to keep in sync
- Can be imported by container

**Cons:**
- Migration effort

### Option B: Shared package via npm/git
Publish callout-processor as npm package or git submodule

**Pros:**
- Clear separation
- Can version independently

**Cons:**
- Sync overhead
- Two places to update

---

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Can run `bun callout:detect --pdf apps/sample-plan.pdf --output ./output`
- [ ] Outputs annotated PNG with rectangles around detected callouts
- [ ] Outputs JSON with markers matching production format
- [ ] Uses same DPI/rotation settings as production backend
- [ ] Can optionally generate PMTiles for verification

---

## Files to Reference

**Source (backend-dev):**
- `packages/callout-processor/src/index.ts` - CLI entry point
- `packages/callout-processor/src/services/cvLLMDetection.ts` - Detection logic
- `packages/callout-processor/src/services/annotateImage.py` - Debug image generation

**Production (main repo):**
- `apps/backend/container/server.py` - Current detection implementation
- `apps/backend/container/requirements.txt` - Python dependencies

title: Replace DZI tiles with high-res JPEG + local caching
description:
Remove tile-based architecture in favor of single high-res JPEG per sheet with local caching.

## Why
- Tiles cause constant API calls during pan/zoom
- Complex caching story for offline
- Tiling process adds backend complexity

## New Architecture
1. Backend exports high-res JPEG (250-300 DPI) per sheet instead of tiles
2. Thumbnail already exists as fallback
3. Mobile downloads high-res to local storage (expo-file-system)
4. OpenSeadragon loads local file
5. Falls back to thumbnail if high-res not downloaded
6. Users can clear high-res cache in Settings to free space

## Benefits
- Simpler backend (remove tile generation)
- One download per sheet instead of hundreds of tile requests
- Offline by default once downloaded
- Better zoom quality (higher DPI)
- Lighter app logic

title: Implement plan text search
description:
## Overview
Full-text search across all plan sheets using OCR-extracted text. Field workers can find specific items like "Panel E-4" across all sheets instantly.

## Agent Assignment
@agent-backend + @agent-frontend-mobile

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] OCR text stored with sheet metadata during processing
- [ ] Full-text search index built (PostgreSQL FTS or Typesense)
- [ ] Search endpoint returns matches with snippets
- [ ] Results grouped by sheet with match count
- [ ] Search highlights matching text in snippet
- [ ] Tapping result navigates to sheet
- [ ] Search debounced (300ms after typing stops)
- [ ] Recent searches saved locally
- [ ] Search latency < 200ms for typical queries
- [ ] Voice note transcriptions included in search

## Maestro Test Requirements
```yaml
appId: com.sitelink.app
---
# Test Search Flow
- launchApp
- tapOn: "Plans"
- tapOn:
    id: "search-icon"
- inputText:
    id: "search-input"
    text: "Panel E-4"
- wait: 500  # Debounce
- assertVisible: "Found on 3 sheets"
- assertVisible: "E-401"
- assertVisible: "PANEL E-4"

# Test Navigation
- tapOn: "E-401"
- waitForAnimationToEnd
- assertVisible: "Electrical Plan"
# Search term should be highlighted on sheet (visual verification)
```

## UI Specifications
- Search screen: Full screen with back button
- Search input: 52pt height, search icon, clear button
- Results header: "Found on X sheets"
- Result card: Sheet number, match count, snippet with highlight
- Snippet: "...circuit from PANEL E-4 to junction..."
- Highlight: Bold or yellow background on matching text
- Empty state: "Search for text on your plans"
- No results: "No matches found for 'query'"

## Search Index Structure
```sql
-- Full-text search table
CREATE TABLE sheet_text_search (
  sheet_id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
  project_id TEXT,
  sheet_number TEXT,
  sheet_title TEXT,
  full_text TEXT,
  -- PostgreSQL FTS
  search_vector TSVECTOR GENERATED ALWAYS AS (
    to_tsvector('english', full_text)
  ) STORED
);

CREATE INDEX idx_sheet_search ON sheet_text_search USING GIN(search_vector);

-- Query
SELECT sheet_id, sheet_number, sheet_title,
       ts_headline('english', full_text, query) as snippet,
       ts_rank(search_vector, query) as rank
FROM sheet_text_search, plainto_tsquery('english', $1) query
WHERE search_vector @@ query
ORDER BY rank DESC
LIMIT 20;
```

## Design Notes
- OCR during plan processing extracts ~10KB text/sheet
- Use PostgreSQL on Neon or Supabase for FTS
- Alternative: Typesense for dedicated search
- Include voice transcriptions in search corpus
- Cache recent search results locally

title: Detect additional callout symbol types in callout-processor-v3
description:
Implement detection for additional callout symbol types in callout-processor-v3, based on PSPC National CADD Standard.

## Callout Types to Detect

### 2.1 Detail Callout Symbols
- **Shape**: Plain circle (outlined, not filled)
- **Content inside**:
  - Simple: `1` (just the detail number)
  - With ref: `1` on top, `X2` below (horizontal divider)
  - Full: `1` on top, `X1 | X2` split on bottom
- **Components**:
  - 1 = Detail identification number
  - X1 = Sheet number where detail callout is located
  - X2 = Sheet number where detail view is drawn

### 2.2 Elevation Callout Symbols
- **Shape**: Circle with ONE small filled triangle attached at top (pointing outward)
- **Content inside**:
  - Simple: `2` (elevation number)
  - With ref: `2 / X2`
  - Full: `2` on top, `X1 | X2` on bottom
- **Components**:
  - 2 = Elevation identification number
  - X1 = Sheet number where elevation callout is located
  - X2 = Sheet number where elevation view is drawn

### 2.3 Section Callout Symbols (Circle Type)
- **Shape**: Circle with TWO small filled triangles on opposite sides (left & right, pointing outward)
- **Content inside**:
  - Simple: `A` (section letter)
  - With ref: `A / X2`
  - Full: `A` on top, `X1 | X2` on bottom
- **Components**:
  - A = Section identification letter
  - X1 = Sheet number where section callout is located
  - X2 = Sheet number where section view is drawn

## Detection Strategy

1. **Detail Circles**: Find plain circles (no attached triangles), OCR text inside
2. **Elevation Circles**: Find circles with exactly ONE small triangle attached at edge
3. **Section Circles**: Find circles with exactly TWO small triangles on opposite sides

## Reference
PSPC National CADD Standard - Annex B: Symbols and graphics (docs/PSPC National CADD Standard - Callout Symbols.pdf)
close_reason: Implemented detection for additional callout symbol types: detail (0 triangles), elevation (1 triangle at top), and section circle (3 triangles). Added find_circles(), find_small_triangles_near_circle(), classify_circle_callout(), extract_text_inside_circle(), parse_callout_label(), and detect_circle_callouts() functions. Updated process_pdf() to integrate both triangle-based and circle-based detection with color-coded annotations.

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
## Detection Strategy - Corrected Triangle Counts

Based on closer inspection of PSPC standard section callout symbols:

### Classification by Triangle Count

| Callout Type | Triangle Count | Triangle Positions |
|--------------|----------------|-------------------|
| **Detail** | 0 | None (plain circle) |
| **Elevation** | 1 | Top only (pointing up) |
| **Section** | 3 | Top + Left + Right (pointing outward) |

### Approach (Similar to y8m triangle detection)

**Circle-first strategy:**
1. Find circles using HoughCircles or contour analysis
2. For each circle, search its perimeter for small attached triangles
3. Count triangles and their positions to classify:
   - **0 triangles** ‚Üí Detail callout
   - **1 triangle (top)** ‚Üí Elevation callout
   - **3 triangles (top + sides)** ‚Üí Section circle callout
4. OCR the text INSIDE the circle (not around it like y8m)
5. Validate text matches expected patterns
6. Deduplicate results

### Key Differences from y8m (Section Cut Markers)

| Aspect | Triangle Detection (y8m) | Circle Detection (0kt) |
|--------|-------------------------|------------------------|
| Primary shape | Filled triangle | Outlined circle |
| Text location | NEAR the shape | INSIDE the shape |
| Classification | All are 'section cut' type | Count triangles to classify |
| Triangle role | The callout itself | Modifier attached to circle |

### Techniques to Reuse from y8m
- Adaptive thresholding for shape detection
- Contour analysis for finding attached triangles
- PaddleOCR for text extraction
- Pattern validation regex
- Distance-based deduplication

### New Challenge
Detecting the spatial relationship between circles and their attached triangles - need to find small triangles that touch or are very close to a circle's edge at specific positions (top, left, right).

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
## Callout Component Structure (from PSPC Standard)

Each callout type has specific components that must be parsed and stored as marker properties.

### Component Breakdown by Type

**Detail Callout:**
| Component | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| `1` (number) | Detail identification number |
| `X1` | Sheet number where detail callout is located |
| `X2` | Sheet number where detail view is drawn |

**Elevation Callout:**
| Component | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| `2` (number) | Elevation identification number |
| `X1` | Sheet number where elevation callout is located |
| `X2` | Sheet number where elevation view is drawn |

**Section Callout:**
| Component | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| `A` (letter) | Section identification letter |
| `X1` | Sheet number where section callout is located |
| `X2` | Sheet number where section view is drawn |

### Label Format Parsing

**Format 1 - Simple:** `3` or `A`
- Just the identifier, no sheet references

**Format 2 - With View Ref:** `3/A5` or `A/X2`
- Top = identifier
- Bottom = X2 (sheet where VIEW is drawn)
- X1 = current sheet (implicit)

**Format 3 - Full Reference:** `3` with `X1|X2` below
- Top = identifier
- Bottom left = X1 (sheet where callout is located)
- Bottom right = X2 (sheet where view is drawn)

### Proposed Marker Schema

```json
{
  "id": "marker-1-0",
  "label": "3/A5",
  "type": "detail" | "elevation" | "section",
  "identifier": "3",
  "viewSheet": "A5",
  "locationSheet": null,
  "x": 0.486,
  "y": 0.583,
  "pixelX": 2480,
  "pixelY": 1927,
  "bbox": { "x1": 2436, "y1": 1909, "x2": 2524, "y2": 1995 },
  "confidence": 0.95
}
```

### Why This Matters

The `viewSheet` property enables the app to:
1. Link callouts to their corresponding detail/elevation/section views
2. Navigate between sheets when user taps a callout
3. Build a cross-reference map of all callouts and views in a plan set

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
## Reference Implementation: sitelink-y8m Triangle Detection

### Working Solution Location
`packages/callout-processor-v3/src/detect.py`

### Key Functions to Study
- `find_filled_triangles()` - Contour analysis with multi-epsilon approximation + convex hull fallback
- `get_text_search_regions()` - Defines search regions around detected shapes
- `extract_text_from_region()` - PaddleOCR text extraction
- `is_valid_section_callout_label()` - Regex pattern validation
- `detect_section_callouts()` - Main detection pipeline with deduplication

### Key Differences: y8m vs 0kt Approach

| Aspect | Triangle Detection (y8m) | Circle Detection (0kt) |
|--------|--------------------------|------------------------|
| Primary shape | Filled triangle | Outlined circle |
| Text location | NEAR the shape (above/below/left/right) | INSIDE the shape |
| Classification | All are 'section cut' type | Count triangles to classify (0=detail, 1=elevation, 3=section) |
| Triangle role | The callout itself | Modifier attached to circle edge |

### Similar Techniques to Reuse
1. **Adaptive thresholding** for shape detection
2. **Contour analysis** for finding triangles (reuse for attached triangle detection)
3. **PaddleOCR** for text extraction
4. **Regex pattern validation** for label formats
5. **Distance-based deduplication** (50px threshold)

### New Challenge for 0kt
Detecting the **spatial relationship** between circles and their attached triangles:
- Find small filled triangles that touch or are very close to a circle's edge
- Determine triangle position relative to circle (top, left, right)
- Count triangles to classify callout type

### Suggested Implementation Order
1. Implement `find_circles()` - detect outlined circles
2. Implement `find_attached_triangles(circle)` - find triangles near circle perimeter
3. Implement `classify_callout(circle, triangles)` - count and position triangles
4. Implement `extract_text_inside_circle()` - OCR the circle interior
5. Implement `parse_callout_label()` - extract identifier, viewSheet, locationSheet
6. Integrate into main detection pipeline with deduplication

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
## Reference Documentation

### PSPC National CADD Standard
`/home/woodson/Code/projects/sitelink/docs/PSPC National CADD Standard - Callout Symbols.pdf`

This PDF contains the official standard for callout symbols including:
- Visual diagrams of all callout types (detail, elevation, section)
- Component descriptions (identifier, X1, X2)
- Label format examples

**Always refer to this PDF** if you need to verify callout shapes, triangle positions, or label formats.

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
## Improvements Added (Post-Close)

After initial testing revealed false positives (north arrows, dimension bubbles, corner details), added two filtering layers:

### 1. Geometric Filter (`is_callout_circle`)
- Checks interior brightness (rejects filled circles)
- Verifies outline exists (dark ring around edge)
- Rejects circles with complex/dark interiors

### 2. Strict Text Validation (`is_valid_circle_callout_label`)
- Explicit reject list: NORTH, SCALE, DIMENSION, SIZE, OFFER, FOUND, etc.
- Rejects 3+ consecutive letters (catches words)
- Only accepts PSPC-compliant patterns:
  - Simple: "1", "A", "AA"
  - With ref: "3/A5", "A/B2"
  - Full: "1 A1 A5"

### Results
- Raw candidates: 62 ‚Üí After filtering: 12
- False positives (north arrows, dimensions) eliminated
- Test output: `output-test-0kt/sheet-2/filtered.png`

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
**Key Finding: CV + Split OCR for Circle Callouts**

Circle callouts with divided text (e.g., '2/A6') require a combined approach:

1. **OCR alone fails** - It sees the horizontal dividing line as a graphic element, not a '/' character. OCR outputs something like '2 A6' or just '2' instead of '2/A6'.

2. **Solution: Computer Vision + Split OCR**
   - Use CV (HoughLinesP) to detect the horizontal dividing line inside the circle
   - Get the Y position of the line
   - OCR the region ABOVE the line ‚Üí '2'
   - OCR the region BELOW the line ‚Üí 'A6'
   - Combine programmatically with '/' ‚Üí '2/A6'

3. **Implementation**:
   - `find_horizontal_line_inside()` - detects line and returns Y position
   - `extract_text_inside_circle()` - splits at line, OCRs each part, combines

This approach correctly extracts labels like '2/A6', '1/A6' that were previously missed or incorrectly read.

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
**Finding: Detail callouts with text inside are missed by contour-based detection**

**Problem:**
- `find_detail_circles` uses contour-based detection with strict circularity (>0.85)
- Circles with text inside (e.g., '8/A7') have LOW circularity (~0.7) because the contour traces the entire shape including the text
- HoughCircles finds these circles correctly because it detects circular EDGES, ignoring interior content

**Example:** The '8/A7' callout at (2930, 1038):
- HoughCircles: ‚úì Finds it (r=31)
- Contour circularity: 0.705 < 0.85 threshold ‚Üí ‚úó Rejected

**Recommendation:** Use HoughCircles for ALL circle detection, then classify:
```
HoughCircles finds ALL circles
       ‚îÇ
       ‚ñº
Has dark pixels above? (triangle)
  ‚îÇ Yes ‚Üí Elevation/Section callout  
  ‚îÇ No  ‚Üí Detail callout
```

**Regression risk: LOW** - Current detections ('1', '2', '2/A6', '1/A6') are all found by HoughCircles. OCR validation remains as safety net.

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
**Fix: False positive filtering for single-letter circles**

Problem:
- Circles with single letters like 'G' were being incorrectly detected as detail callouts
- Two-letter combinations like 'TY', 'GI', 'ON' from OCR noise were also being detected

Root cause:
- Label validation was too permissive - accepted any 1-2 letter combination
- Triangle detection used simple dark pixel ratio instead of actual shape detection

Solution:
1. Split validation into type-specific functions:
   - `is_valid_detail_callout_label()`: Only accepts NUMBERS (1, 2, 10) or divided format (1/A5)
   - `is_valid_elevation_section_label()`: Accepts numbers OR single letters (A, B, C)
   
2. Per PSPC standard:
   - Detail callouts use NUMBERS as identifiers
   - Section callouts use SINGLE LETTERS (A-Z), not arbitrary letter pairs
   
3. Improved triangle detection:
   - Now uses actual triangular shape detection via `find_small_triangles_near_circle()`
   - Previously just checked dark pixel ratio above circle

Result: 'G' and other grid marker circles no longer detected as callouts, while valid callouts like '8/A7', '1/A6' etc. are still correctly detected.

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
**Fix: Filter out title callouts and letters-in-words**

Two additional false positive sources identified and fixed:

1. **Title callouts** (circles '1' and '2' for 'LOWER ROOF...' etc.)
   - Root cause: Title callouts per PSPC 2.4 have circle + horizontal line extending RIGHT + title text + scale
   - These are NOT reference callouts - they label views on the current sheet
   - Fix: `check_horizontal_line_extending_right()` detects lines extending from circle's right edge
   - If line found ‚Üí filter out

2. **Letters in words** (like 'O' from 'ROOF' detected as 'S:C')
   - Root cause: HoughCircles detects ANY circular shape, including letter O
   - The O passes whiteness check (white inside) and nearby shapes trigger triangle detection
   - OCR misreads O as C
   - Fix: `check_is_letter_in_word()` checks for text on BOTH left AND right sides
   - Real callout circles are standalone, letters in words have text on both sides
   - If text on both sides ‚Üí filter out

Result: Clean detection with no title callout or letter-in-word false positives.

```typescript
function SheetList({ projectId }: { projectId: string }) {
```

title: Fix callout marker position mismatch - PDF rotation handling
description:
## Problem Summary

Callout markers detected by the backend appear in **wrong positions** on the mobile app, and we lack a proper way to test/debug the detection pipeline locally.

### Original Issue
- Markers show as large red circles instead of precise rectangles
- Position accuracy cannot be verified without proper tooling

### Key Discovery from Investigation

The `callouts_annotated.png` reference (2550√ó3300) is from a **COMPLETELY DIFFERENT processing run** than the mobile data (5100√ó3300). We cannot compare them because:
- Different dimensions (2550 vs 5100 width)
- Different orientation handling
- Different DPI settings

**Coordinates ARE normalized correctly** - we verified x=3129/5100 and y=465/3300 match exactly.

---

## Root Problem: No Local Testing Workflow

Unlike `sitelink_backend-dev/packages/callout-processor` which has a standalone CLI for testing, the main repo lacks:

1. **Quick PDF ‚Üí Detection ‚Üí Debug Image workflow**
2. **Local reference image generation** at same settings as production
3. **Isolated testing** without full backend deployment
4. **Coordinate verification tools**

---

## Goals

### Primary Goal
Allow users to **click on callout symbols to navigate to the referenced sheet**.

### Prerequisite (Blocking)
**Set up local callout processor testing** - we need to be able to:
1. Process a PDF locally
2. Generate annotated debug images
3. Compare with mobile rendering
4. Iterate on detection/coordinate issues

---

## Recommended Approach

### Option A: Port callout-processor to main repo
Move/adapt `sitelink_backend-dev/packages/callout-processor` into the main sitelink monorepo as a shared package that can be:
- Imported by the backend container
- Run standalone for testing
- Used to generate PMTiles for verification

### Option B: Sync callout-processor as submodule
Keep it separate but ensure settings match production exactly.

---

## Current Status

Investigation complete. Blocking on local testing infrastructure before we can verify/fix marker positions.

## Key Files

**Backend:**
- `/apps/backend/container/server.py` - PDF render, callout detection, tile generation

**Mobile:**
- `/apps/mobile/components/plans/viewer/pmtiles-viewer.tsx` - Marker rendering (32px circles)

**Reference (backend-dev):**
- `/packages/callout-processor/` - Standalone CV + LLM detection with CLI

comments.author: woodson
comments.text:
## Critical Finding: Dimension Mismatch Confirmed

### Evidence

| Source | Dimensions | Orientation |
|--------|------------|-------------|
| `callouts_annotated.png` (backend-dev) | **2550 √ó 3300** | Portrait |
| Mobile database sheets | **5100 √ó 3300** | Landscape |
| PDF metadata | 792 √ó 1224 pts with **`/Rotate: 270`** | Has rotation\! |

### PDF Analysis

The sample-plan.pdf has:
- **Page size**: 792 √ó 1224 pts (11" √ó 17" tabloid)
- **Page rotation**: 270¬∞ embedded in PDF metadata

At 300 DPI:
- **Without rotation**: 3300 √ó 5100 (portrait)
- **With 270¬∞ rotation**: 5100 √ó 3300 (landscape) ‚Üê Matches mobile DB

### The Problem

The `callouts_annotated.png` (2550√ó3300) does NOT match either:
- It's not 300 DPI with rotation (would be 5100√ó3300)
- It's not 300 DPI without rotation (would be 3300√ó5100)
- It appears to be from a **different processing run** or **different DPI setting**

### Callout Processor Analysis

The backend-dev callout processor has:
1. **Default DPI of 200** in `pdfProcessor.ts`, but API overrides to 300
2. **Hardcoded fallback of 2550√ó3300** in `ensembleDetection.ts` when hyperlink positions can't be inferred
3. **No explicit rotation handling** - relies on VIPS to honor PDF /Rotate metadata

### Root Cause Hypothesis

The dimension mismatch suggests:
1. `callouts_annotated.png` was generated from a test run with different settings
2. OR the callout processor used the hardcoded 2550√ó3300 fallback
3. The mobile app received data from a DIFFERENT processing run at 5100√ó3300

### Next Steps

1. Need to trace what dimensions the ACTUAL callout detection used when processing the mobile data
2. Verify if markers were normalized against 2550√ó3300 or 5100√ó3300
3. Check if there's a rotation transform being applied (or not) inconsistently

comments.text:
## Marker Coordinate Analysis

### Stored Marker Data (from mobile DB)

Example markers for sheet-1 (A2):
```
label  | x (normalized) | y (normalized) | confidence
-------|----------------|----------------|------------
2/A6   | 0.6135         | 0.1409         | 0.9
```

- Displayed on **5100√ó3300** ‚Üí pixel 3129 (2x further right\!)

If markers were detected on **5100√ó3300** image:

- Displayed correctly

### The Visual Evidence

Looking at the device screenshot vs callouts_annotated.png:

- Reference shows callouts spread across **different areas** (accounting for rotation)
- The positions don't match even after mental rotation adjustment

### Conclusion

The normalized coordinates were calculated against a **different image dimension** than what the mobile viewer is using. This causes:
1. X-axis shift (if width differs)
2. Y-axis shift (if height differs)  
3. Complete positional mismatch when both differ

### Key Question to Answer

What dimensions did the backend use when it emitted the `sheetCalloutsDetected` event that populated the mobile database? We need to trace the actual processing run, not the test output in backend-dev.

From eventlog, marker for sheet-1:

### Critical Realization

The `callouts_annotated.png` (2550√ó3300) is from a **COMPLETELY DIFFERENT processing run** than the mobile data (5100√ó3300). 

**We cannot use it as a reference for marker positions!**

### Remaining Questions

1. Do the markers actually appear at wrong positions relative to the **actual callout symbols on the plan** (not the reference PNG)?
2. Is the OpenSeadragon viewport transformation working correctly?
3. Could there be a Y-flip or rotation issue in how tiles are rendered vs how markers are positioned?

### Next Step

comments.text:
## CRITICAL: Y-Coordinate System Mismatch Hypothesis

### The Pipeline

| Component | Y=0 Position | Y-Flip Applied? |
|-----------|--------------|-----------------|
| PNG Image | Top | N/A |
| Marker Detection | Top (0-1 norm) | ‚úó NO |
| pyvips dzsave | Top (Google/XYZ) | N/A |
| MBTiles Storage | **Bottom (TMS)** | ‚úì YES (flip_y) |
| PMTiles Tiles | **Bottom (TMS)** | Inherited |
| OpenSeadragon | Top (0-1) | Expects XYZ |
| Marker Positioning | Top (0-1) | ‚úó NO |

### The Problem

1. **Tiles stored in TMS format** (y=0 at bottom) after flip_y() at server.py:1025
2. **Markers positioned using image-space coords** (y=0 at top) with NO Y-flip
3. **Result**: Markers appear vertically offset from actual positions

### Verification Needed

The image DOES display correctly in the app, so either:
- OpenSeadragon handles TMS internally
- PMTiles returns flipped tiles
- OR the Y-flip in tile storage is being undone somewhere

Need to verify if markers are actually vertically flipped vs horizontally offset.

comments.text:
## Summary of Investigation

### What We Confirmed

1. **Marker coordinates ARE normalized correctly** against 5100√ó3300:
   - x = 3129/5100 = 0.6135294117647059 ‚úì (exact match)
   - y = 465/3300 = 0.1409090909090909 ‚úì (exact match)

2. **Mobile database stores 5100√ó3300** for all sheets

3. **PDF has `/Rotate: 270` metadata** - page is 792√ó1224 pts (11"√ó17") rotated

4. **Backend applies rotation via pyvips** ‚Üí produces 5100√ó3300 (landscape) at 300 DPI

### The Comparison Problem

The `callouts_annotated.png` (2550√ó3300, portrait) is from a **COMPLETELY DIFFERENT processing run** than the mobile data (5100√ó3300, landscape).

- Different dimensions (2550 vs 5100 width)
- Different orientation (portrait vs landscape)  
- Cannot be used as reference for mobile marker positions

### Remaining Issues to Address

1. **Marker visual style**: Backend shows tight red RECTANGLES around callout symbols; mobile shows large red CIRCLES (32√ó32px)

2. **Marker SIZE**: The circles are so large they overlap and obscure the actual callout symbols underneath

3. **Verification needed**: Need to confirm markers ARE on actual callout symbols (can't see due to circle size)

### Recommendations

1. **Make markers smaller** - reduce from 32px to ~16px or less
2. **Show as rectangles** - match the visual style from callouts_annotated.png

title: Implement backend API layer with Effect-TS
description:
## Overview
REST API layer using Effect-TS for type-safe, composable backend logic. Runs on Cloudflare Workers with D1 for relational data.

## Agent Assignment
@agent-backend

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Effect-TS service architecture established
- [ ] API routes with proper error handling and validation
- [ ] Request validation using Effect Schema
- [ ] Response serialization matches TypeScript types
- [ ] Rate limiting per user (100 req/min) and organization (1000 req/min)
- [ ] API versioning with /v1 prefix
- [ ] Authentication middleware validates Better-Auth sessions
- [ ] OpenAPI spec auto-generated from schemas
- [ ] Health check endpoint
- [ ] Structured logging with request tracing

## Core Endpoints
```
Authentication:
POST   /v1/auth/session     - Validate session
DELETE /v1/auth/session     - Logout

Projects:
GET    /v1/projects                    - List projects
POST   /v1/projects                    - Create project
GET    /v1/projects/:id                - Get project
PATCH  /v1/projects/:id                - Update project
DELETE /v1/projects/:id                - Archive project
POST   /v1/projects/:id/upload         - Upload plans

Sheets:
GET    /v1/projects/:id/sheets         - List sheets
GET    /v1/sheets/:id                  - Get sheet with markers

Photos:
POST   /v1/photos/presigned            - Get upload URL
GET    /v1/projects/:id/photos         - List project photos
GET    /v1/markers/:id/photos          - List marker photos

Voice Notes:
POST   /v1/voice-notes/presigned       - Get upload URL
POST   /v1/voice-notes/:id/transcribe  - Trigger transcription

AI Features:
POST   /v1/projects/:id/summary        - Generate daily summary
GET    /v1/projects/:id/search         - Search plan text

Sharing:
POST   /v1/projects/:id/share          - Generate share link
GET    /v1/share/:code                 - Get shared project (public)
```

## Example Effect Service
```typescript
// services/ProjectService.ts
import { Effect, Layer } from 'effect'
import { Schema } from '@effect/schema'

const CreateProjectSchema = Schema.Struct({
  name: Schema.String.pipe(Schema.minLength(1), Schema.maxLength(100)),
  address: Schema.optional(Schema.String),
})

export class ProjectService extends Effect.Service<ProjectService>()('ProjectService', {
  effect: Effect.gen(function* () {
    const db = yield* D1Service
    const store = yield* LiveStoreService
    
    return {
      create: (input: typeof CreateProjectSchema.Type) =>
        Effect.gen(function* () {
          const id = crypto.randomUUID()
          yield* store.commit(events.projectCreated({ id, ...input }))
          return { id }
        }),
    }
  }),
}) {}
```

## Design Notes
- Use Effect-TS for all business logic
- Bun.serve for HTTP handling on Workers
- D1 for relational queries (users, organizations, subscriptions)
- LiveStore for domain events (projects, photos, etc.)
- Separate read models from event store

title: Spike: Test PMTiles + OpenSeadragon integration in local Bun app
description:
## Overview
Create a minimal proof-of-concept to verify PMTiles can be used with OpenSeadragon before integrating into the mobile app.

## Goal
Validate that:
1. PMTiles library can extract tiles from a .pmtiles file
2. OpenSeadragon can display those tiles via custom tile source
3. The integration pattern works before adding React Native complexity

## Setup
```bash
mkdir pmtiles-osd-spike && cd pmtiles-osd-spike
bun init
bun add openseadragon pmtiles react react-dom
bun add -d vite @vitejs/plugin-react
```

## Test Plan

### 1. Generate a test PMTiles file
Use VIPS pipeline on a sample construction plan:
```bash
# Convert PDF/image to tiles
vips dzsave sample-plan.jpg tmp_tiles --layout google --suffix ".webp[Q=75]"

# Pack with ZYX scheme (fixes axis flip)
mb-util tmp_tiles/ plan.mbtiles --scheme=zyx --image_format=webp

# Convert to PMTiles
pmtiles convert plan.mbtiles plan.pmtiles
```

### 2. Create custom OpenSeadragon TileSource
Override tile loading to fetch from PMTiles:
- Use pmtiles.getZxy(level, x, y) to get tile data
- Convert to blob URL or base64
- Feed to OpenSeadragon

### 3. Verify in browser
- Tiles load correctly at all zoom levels
- Pan/zoom is smooth
- No coordinate axis issues (plan not mirrored/flipped)
- Memory usage is reasonable

## Success Criteria
- [ ] PMTiles file loads without errors
- [ ] OpenSeadragon displays the plan correctly
- [ ] Zoom levels work (tiles switch appropriately)
- [ ] Plan orientation is correct (not flipped)
- [ ] Document the working pattern for mobile integration

## Notes
- If downloadTileStart does not work reliably, try imageLoader.addJob override pattern from old_docs-2.md
- PMTiles uses ZXY coordinates - verify alignment with OpenSeadragon expectations
- This spike informs the mobile implementation approach
notes:
## ‚úÖ Integration Verified

Successfully demonstrated PMTiles + OpenSeadragon integration!

### What Works
- ‚úÖ PMTiles file generation at 300 DPI (one-pass pipeline)
- ‚úÖ OpenSeadragon loads and displays tiles correctly
- ‚úÖ imageLoader.addJob override pattern works
- ‚úÖ Tiles fetched via pmtiles.getZxy(z, x, y)
- ‚úÖ Converted to blob URLs and displayed
- ‚úÖ Smooth pan and zoom functionality
- ‚úÖ No coordinate axis issues (ZYX scheme correct)

### Pipeline (Optimized)
```bash
# One-pass: PDF ‚Üí DZI tiles at 300 DPI
vips dzsave "plan.pdf[dpi=300]" tmp_tiles --layout google --suffix ".webp[Q=75]"

# Pack to MBTiles with ZYX scheme
../mbutil_zyx/mb-util-zyx tmp_tiles/ plan.mbtiles --scheme=zyx --image_format=webp

# Convert to PMTiles
pmtiles convert plan.mbtiles plan.pmtiles
```

### File Size
Test plan (letter-size PDF at 300 DPI): **245KB** PMTiles file

### Key Learnings
1. **One-pass is better**: No need for intermediate PNG - VIPS can render PDF and tile in one operation
2. **DPI matters**: Initial test at low DPI was blurry - 300 DPI produces sharp, readable plans
3. **ZYX scheme essential**: Prevents axis flip/mirroring issues
4. **imageLoader override works perfectly**: Clean interception of tile requests

### Ready for Mobile Integration
The pattern is proven and ready to implement in React Native with:
- Native Actions pattern (fetch tiles in RN, pass base64 to WebView)
- Local PMTiles file access
- Progressive loading (fallback ‚Üí tiled)

title: Plan Upload UX Overhaul: Filename-based folders + async processing feedback
description:
## Problem

Currently when uploading a plan PDF:
1. **Folder naming is wrong**: Sheets are grouped into folders by 'discipline' (Architectural, Structural, Unfiled sheets) instead of by the original PDF filename
2. **No async feedback**: User sees 'Uploading Plan' modal that blocks until processing completes, instead of async background processing with visual feedback
3. **Sheet viewer needs verification**: Ensure clicking sheets shows plan with callout markers

## Current Architecture

The backend pipeline is already async (4 stages: image gen ‚Üí metadata ‚Üí callouts ‚Üí tiles), but the mobile UI doesn't reflect this properly.

### Current folder logic (use-sheets.ts):
```typescript
const discipline = sheet.discipline || 'Unfiled sheets'
groupedByDiscipline[discipline].push(sheet)
```

### What we need:
```typescript
const folderName = sheet.planName || 'Unknown Plan' // Original PDF filename without extension
groupedByPlan[folderName].push(sheet)
```

## Requirements

### 1. Folder Structure Change
- Folder name = original PDF filename (without .pdf extension)
- All sheets from that plan go into that folder
- E.g., 'sample-plan.pdf' ‚Üí folder named 'sample-plan' containing A1, Sheet 2, Sheet 3, etc.

### 2. Async Upload UX
- **Immediate**: Create folder with processing indicator (spinner icon OR animated border showing progress)
- **Background**: Processing continues in backend
- **Completion**: Remove processing indicator, show final sheet count
- **Error handling**: Show error state if processing fails

### 3. Sheet Viewer Verification
- Tapping a sheet opens the plan viewer
- Callout markers display at correct positions
- Markers are interactive (tap to see details)

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1: Data Model Changes
1. Add `planName` field to plans table (stores original filename)
2. Update `planUploaded` event to include filename
3. Update materializer to store planName
4. Ensure sheets have reference to their parent plan's name

### Phase 2: Folder Display Changes
1. Update `use-sheets.ts` to group by planName instead of discipline
2. Update `plan-selector.tsx` to display plan-based folders
3. Add processing state indicator to folder UI

### Phase 3: Upload UX Changes
1. Update `use-plan-upload.ts` to emit event immediately with planName
2. Add `processingStatus` field to plans (pending/processing/completed/failed)
3. Create animated folder component with progress indicator
4. Update UI to show processing state per-plan

### Phase 4: Sheet Viewer Verification
1. Test marker display on uploaded sheets
2. Verify marker coordinates are correct
3. Test marker interaction (tap ‚Üí detail sheet)

## Files to Modify

- `packages/domain/src/events.ts` - Add planName to events
- `packages/domain/src/tables.ts` - Add planName, processingStatus to plans

## Overview

Implement a local-first PDF processing pipeline with a **professional, minimalistic UI/UX** that:
1. Keeps users informed without overwhelming them
2. Uses subtle animations and smooth transitions
3. Provides clear processing status at every stage
4. Enables intuitive callout review workflow

## UI/UX Requirements (CRITICAL)

### Design Principles
- **Clarity over complexity** - User should ALWAYS know what's happening
- **Minimalistic** - Clean interface, no visual clutter
- **Professional** - Wealthsimple-inspired aesthetic
- **Smooth animations** - React Native Reanimated for all transitions
- **Progressive disclosure** - Show details on demand, not by default

### Processing States UI

1. **Upload State** - Subtle progress bar, checkmark animation on complete
2. **Pending Sync (Offline)** - Gentle pulsing indicator, 'Waiting for connection'
3. **Processing State** - Circular progress, stage description with crossfade
4. **Ready State** - Success checkmark with scale animation

### Callout Review UX (IMPORTANT)
- Review queue showing items needing attention
- Detail view with zoomed callout crop
- Simple yes/no/edit actions
- Swipe gestures for quick review

## Reference Implementations

### Metadata & Callout Detection
- Branch: `backend-dev`
- Path: `packages/callout-processor/`
- Files: README.md, API.md, src/services/cvLLMDetection.ts

### PMTiles + OpenSeadragon

- Files: README.md, src/components/PMTilesViewer.tsx
- Mobile MUST use this pattern for processed plan viewing

## Processing Pipeline

Stage 1: Image Generation - PDF to 300 DPI PNG (REUSED by all stages)
Stage 2: Metadata Extraction - OCR sheet names, build validSheets list
Stage 3: Callout Detection - OpenCV + LLM, validate against validSheets
Stage 4: PMTiles Generation - VIPS tiles to PMTiles format

## Event Sourcing

All stages commit events to LiveStore (storeId = organizationId):
- planImageGenerationStarted, sheetImageGenerated

**Result: NOT VIABLE**

title: Improve YOLO Training Dataset: Collect Diverse Production Plans
description:
## Problem

Current validation set (dataset_highres/valid) is small and unrepresentative:
- Only 13 images
- Validation shows 73.8-83.5% recall
- Production shows 44-66% recall
- **Gap: 8-28 percentage points!**

Models trained on this dataset don't generalize to real-world production plans.

## Root Cause

1. **Too small:** 13 validation images can't represent diversity of production plans
2. **Unrepresentative:** Validation plans may be easier/different than production plans
3. **Annotation quality unknown:** Are all 89 callouts per page properly labeled?
4. **Limited diversity:** Need variety in:
   - Drawing types (structural, architectural, MEP, civil)
   - Standards (NCS, CSI, AIA, Canadian)
   - Complexity levels (simple to dense)
   - Plan sizes and scales
   - Callout styles and densities

## Objective

Create a robust, representative dataset with:
- **Training set:** 200+ images from diverse production plans
- **Validation set:** 50+ images representing production complexity
- **Test set:** 30+ images for final evaluation
- **Proper annotations:** All callouts labeled (not just easy ones)
- **Geographic diversity:** US and Canadian plans
- **Standard diversity:** Multiple drawing standards

---

## Data Collection Plan

### Phase 1: Find Public Plan Sources

**US Public Plans:**
- [ ] Search municipal building departments with online plan repositories
- [ ] University architecture libraries (public archives)
- [ ] Government project repositories (federal/state)
- [ ] Open-source construction databases
- [ ] Sample plan libraries from AEC software vendors

**Canadian Public Plans:**
- [ ] Provincial/territorial building departments
- [ ] Municipal plan repositories
- [ ] Canadian university archives
- [ ] Government infrastructure projects
- [ ] Sample plans from Canadian AEC vendors

**Search Strategy:**
- Keywords: "public building plans", "architectural drawings public domain", "structural plans repository"
- Target: 100+ unique plan sets (500+ pages total)
- Focus: Plans with clear callout symbols (circles, triangles)

### Phase 2: Download and Organize

**Directory Structure:**
```
dataset_production/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ raw/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ us/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ structural/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ architectural/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mep/
‚îÇ   ‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ civil/
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ canada/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ structural/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ architectural/
‚îÇ       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mep/
‚îÇ       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ civil/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ processed/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ images/          # Rendered at 72 DPI
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ metadata.json    # Source, type, complexity
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ annotations/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ train/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ valid/
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ test/
```

**Processing:**
- Render PDFs at 72 DPI (consistent with training)
- Extract pages with callouts
- Track metadata (source, type, standard, complexity)
- Aim for 300+ annotatable pages

### Phase 3: Annotation Guidelines

**What to Annotate:**
- ‚úÖ Detail callouts (circles)
- ‚úÖ Elevation callouts (circles with triangles)
- ‚úÖ Section callouts (circles/hexagons)
- ‚úÖ Title blocks
- ‚ùå Text labels (not callouts)
- ‚ùå Grid markers (A, B, C)
- ‚ùå Dimension labels

**Quality Standards:**
- Annotate ALL callouts on a page (not just easy ones)
- Tight bounding boxes around symbols
- Consistent class labels (detail/elevation/section/title)
- Double-check dense areas (20+ callouts per region)
- Verify OCR-readable text inside symbols

**Tools:**
- Roboflow (recommended - exports to YOLO format)
- LabelImg
- CVAT
- Label Studio

### Phase 4: Dataset Split

**Split Strategy (70/20/10):**
- **Training:** 200+ images (70%) - Maximum diversity
- **Validation:** 50+ images (20%) - Representative of production
- **Test:** 30+ images (10%) - Hold-out for final evaluation

**Stratification:**
Ensure each split has:
- Mix of drawing types (structural, arch, MEP)
- Mix of standards (NCS, CSI, AIA, Canadian)
- Mix of complexity (sparse to dense callouts)
- Mix of sources (different municipalities/projects)

**Critical:** Validation and test sets MUST represent production complexity, not just easy examples!

---

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Collected 100+ unique plan sets (500+ pages)
- [ ] Rendered 300+ pages at 72 DPI
- [ ] Annotated 280+ images (all callouts labeled)
- [ ] Created train/val/test split (200/50/30)
- [ ] Validated annotation quality (spot check 10%)
- [ ] Documented sources and metadata
- [ ] Exported to YOLO format (dataset_production/data.yaml)

**Validation:** Test current baseline model on new validation set. Should see similar performance to production (not inflated like current validation).

---

## Resources Needed

- **Time:** 40-60 hours total
  - Collection: 10 hours (web research, downloads)
  - Processing: 5 hours (PDF rendering, organization)
  - Annotation: 30-40 hours (280 images √ó 5-10 min each)
  - QA: 5 hours (validation, corrections)

- **Tools:**
  - Roboflow account (free tier supports 1000 images)
  - Python scripts for PDF rendering
  - Spreadsheet for metadata tracking

- **Help:** Consider outsourcing annotation to:
  - Architecture students (familiar with plans)
  - Annotation services (Scale AI, Labelbox)
  - Internal team members

---

## Success Metrics

**Before (current dataset):**
- Validation recall: 73.8-83.5%
- Production recall: 44-66%
- Gap: 8-28 percentage points

**After (new dataset):**
- Validation recall: 60-70% (realistic)
- Production recall: 60-70% (matches validation)
- Gap: <5 percentage points
- Models generalize to unseen plans

---

## Dependencies

- ‚è∏Ô∏è sitelink-al7: Deferred Steps 3-4 (retraining) until dataset ready
- üîó Requires: Public plan sources (web research)
- üîó Requires: Annotation tool setup

---

## Next Actions

1. **Web search:** Find public plan repositories (US + Canada)
2. **Evaluate sources:** Check plan quality, diversity, accessibility
3. **Download samples:** Get 10-20 plans to test annotation workflow
4. **Set up annotation tool:** Configure Roboflow/CVAT
5. **Annotate pilot batch:** 20 images to refine guidelines
6. **Scale up:** Full annotation of 280+ images

title: Implement plan processing pipeline
description:
## Overview
Backend service that processes uploaded PDFs into high-res image tiles, extracts text via OCR, and detects callout markers for auto-linking. This powers the core plan viewing experience.

## Agent Assignment
@agent-backend

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] PDF upload endpoint accepts multi-page PDFs (up to 500 pages, 100MB)
- [ ] PDF split into individual page images (PNG intermediate)
- [ ] High-res JPEG generated for each page (configurable DPI, default 150)
- [ ] OCR extracts all text with bounding boxes using PaddleOCR
- [ ] Sheet metadata extracted: sheet number (e.g., "A-101"), title, discipline
- [ ] Marker detection identifies callout symbols (circles, hexagons, triangles)
- [ ] Two-stage detection: geometric (OpenCV) + LLM validation (Gemini)
- [ ] Markers linked to target sheets based on text content
- [ ] Confidence score (0-100%) assigned to each marker link
- [ ] Progress events sent via webhook during processing
- [ ] All artifacts stored in R2 with organized paths
- [ ] Processing completes within target: ~30 sec/page

## Example Processing Flow
```
Input: architectural_plans.pdf (47 pages, 45MB)

Step 1: Split PDF (5 seconds)
- Extract 47 page images

Step 2: Generate Tiles (23 minutes @ 30 sec/page)
- Convert each page to high-res JPEG
- Store in R2: /orgs/{orgId}/plans/{projectId}/sheets/{sheetId}.jpg

Step 3: OCR Extraction (8 minutes @ 10 sec/page)
- Extract text with positions
- Identify sheet number, title, discipline

Step 4: Marker Detection (4 minutes @ 5 sec/page)
- Detect 150+ callout markers
- Validate with LLM for 91.5% recall
- Link markers to target sheets

Output:
- sheetsReceived event with 47 sheet records
- markersReceived event with 150+ marker records
- Processing time: ~35 minutes total
```

## API Endpoints
```
POST /v1/projects/:projectId/upload
Body: multipart/form-data with PDF file
Response: { uploadId, estimatedTime }

GET /v1/uploads/:uploadId/status
Response: { status, progress, currentStep, sheetsProcessed, totalSheets }

Webhook: POST {callbackUrl}
Body: { uploadId, status, progress, message }
```

## Design Notes
- Use Cloudflare Workers for upload handling
- Queue processing to separate worker for long-running tasks
- pdf-lib or pdf2pic for PDF splitting
- sharp for image conversion
- PaddleOCR via Python worker or Cloudflare AI
- OpenCV for geometric detection
- Gemini 2.0 Flash for marker validation
- R2 for all file storage

title: Plan: Integrate sitelink-interpreter with mobile app and Cloudflare backend
description:
## Objective
Create an integration plan for connecting the sitelink-interpreter callout detection system with:
1. Mobile app (Expo/React Native)
2. Backend on Cloudflare Workers (using Cloudflare Containers)

## Background Context

### Current Solution Architecture

**Callout Detection Pipeline** (packages/callout-processor-v5):
- YOLO v6 model trained on 72 DPI images with SAHI tiling
- Detects 3 callout classes: detail, elevation, title
- Performance: 96.5%+ precision and recall

**Text Extraction** (Gemini Flash 2 via OpenRouter):
- Uses `--gemini` flag with `--hires-image` for high-resolution crops
- YOLO detection runs on 72 DPI, but crops taken from 150 DPI original
- Tight bbox crops (no padding) to avoid surrounding text confusion
- Batched API calls (10 crops per request) for efficiency
- Extracts identifier (detail number) and target_sheet (sheet reference)

**Sheet Info Extraction** (extract_sheet_info_gemini.py):
- Extracts sheet_number and sheet_title from title block region
- Crops bottom-right 40% of page (where title blocks live)
- Batched processing (10 pages per API call)
- Returns both sheet_number (e.g., "S2.0") and sheet_title (e.g., "FOUNDATION PLAN")

### Working Frontend Example

**SiteLink Plan Explorer** (packages/sitelink-interpreter):
- Browser-based UI at localhost:3456
- Built with Bun + React (no Vite, uses Bun.serve with HTML imports)
- Features:
  - PDF upload with automatic sheet extraction
  - Interactive canvas with callout bounding boxes
  - Sheet sidebar showing sheet_number and sheet_title
  - Provenance panel showing callout details and navigation
  - Click-to-navigate between referenced sheets

**Key Files to Reference**:
- `src/api/server.ts` - Bun.serve API with all endpoints
- `src/ui/explorer.tsx` - Main React UI component
- `src/extraction/yolo-extraction.ts` - Detection pipeline integration
- `src/ingestion/index.ts` - PDF ingestion with Gemini sheet info extraction

### API Endpoints (Current)

| Endpoint | Method | Description |
|----------|--------|-------------|
| `/api/upload` | POST | Upload PDF, run legacy extraction |
| `/api/detect` | POST | Upload PDF, run YOLO + Gemini extraction |
| `/api/sheets` | GET | List all sheets with sheet_number, sheet_title |
| `/api/sheets/:id` | GET | Get single sheet details |
| `/api/sheets/:id/entities` | GET | Get callouts for a sheet |
| `/api/sheets/:id/detect` | POST | Run detection on single sheet |
| `/api/entities/:id/provenance` | GET | Get callout provenance chain |

## Cloudflare Container Requirements

**Research Needed**: Cloudflare Containers (beta)
- How to containerize the Python detection pipeline
- GPU requirements for YOLO inference
- Memory requirements for large PDFs
- Cold start implications

**Dependencies**:
- Python 3.10+
- OpenCV, NumPy, Pillow
- Ultralytics YOLO
- PaddleOCR (optional, fallback)
- httpx (for OpenRouter API)

**Model Files**:
- YOLO weights: ~6MB (packages/callout-processor-v6-experimental/weights/best.pt)

## Questions to Answer

1. **Container Architecture**:
   - Single container with Python + YOLO?
   - Separate containers for detection vs text extraction?
   - How to handle OPENROUTER_API_KEY secrets?

2. **API Design**:
   - How should mobile app call the detection service?
   - Through Cloudflare backend proxy?
   - WebSocket/SSE for progress updates during processing?

3. **Data Flow**:
   - PDFs uploaded to R2 storage?
   - Detection results stored in D1 or LiveStore?
   - How to serve callout crop images to mobile?

4. **Sheet Info Integration**:
   - How to surface sheet_number and sheet_title in mobile UI?
   - How to link callouts to sheets for navigation?
   - PMTiles integration for zoomable sheet viewing?

5. **Local Development**:
   - How to run containerized interpreter alongside wrangler dev?
   - Docker Compose setup for local testing?
   - How to test mobile ‚Üí backend ‚Üí container flow locally?

## Deliverables

1. Architecture diagram showing:
   - Mobile app ‚Üí Cloudflare Worker ‚Üí Container ‚Üí R2/D1
   - Data flow for upload, detection, and retrieval

2. API endpoint specifications for mobile consumption

3. Data models/schema changes for LiveStore events

4. Implementation tickets with dependencies:
   - Containerize sitelink-interpreter
   - Create Cloudflare Worker proxy endpoints
   - Integrate detection results into mobile UI
   - Add sheet navigation to mobile plan viewer

## References

- Commit 2bb7f9278: High-res Gemini extraction implementation
- sitelink-i78: High-res Gemini extraction ticket (closed)
- packages/callout-processor-v5/README.md: Detection documentation
- packages/sitelink-interpreter/CLAUDE.md: Development conventions

title: Public Plan Sources & Dataset Strategy (Reference)
description:
## Purpose

**Reference documentation** for public architectural/structural plan sources and dataset collection strategy for YOLO callout detection training.

This bead serves as a knowledge base for future dataset improvement efforts.

---

## Research Question: Structural Plans Only or All Plan Types?

### **Answer: FOCUS ON STRUCTURAL PLANS (70-80%), Include Others for Diversity**

**Why prioritize structural plans:**

‚úÖ **Highest callout density** - 20-50+ callouts per page vs 5-15 on architectural  
‚úÖ **Consistent symbols** - Detail circles and elevation triangles are standard across projects  
‚úÖ **NCS compliance** - Most follow National CAD Standard for callout formatting  
‚úÖ **Best training ROI** - Dense annotations = more training signal per page  
‚úÖ **Our target use case** - Structural plans are primary user need  

**Include other types (20-30%):**
- **Architectural foundation/framing plans** - Have structural-like callouts
- **MEP coordination drawings** - Equipment detail callouts
- **Avoid:** Floor plans, site plans with no callouts

**Recommended ratio:**
- 70% Structural (foundation, framing, details)
- 20% Architectural (foundation plans, wall sections)
- 10% MEP (equipment details, riser diagrams)

---

title: Text Label Detection for Construction Plan Callouts
description:
Implement text detection solution to extract callout labels (e.g., '17/S2.0') from construction plans.

Problem: YOLOv8n detects symbols (96.6% mAP50) but OCR returns empty strings (12% confidence) because text labels are positioned ADJACENT to symbols, not inside YOLO bounding boxes. Even with 150% padding expansion, text regions are missed.

Solution Options (ranked):
1. Smart Post-Processing (RECOMMENDED): OpenCV text region finding near symbols + PaddleOCR (70-85% accuracy, no annotation)
2. Grounding DINO: Text prompts for open-vocab detection (40-70% accuracy, experimental, model in repo)
3. Train YOLO for Text: Add 4th class (85-95% accuracy, requires re-annotation)
4. Alternative OCR: Try EasyOCR/Tesseract/TrOCR (50-65% accuracy)

Implementation Plan:
- Phase 1: Test Grounding DINO + smart post-processing, choose best (2-3 days)
- Phase 2: Implement chosen method in api_detect.py (3-5 days)
- Phase 3: Test on sitelink-interpreter UI, validate (2-3 days)
- Phase 4: Deploy and monitor (1 day)

Success Metrics:
- >80% text labels detected
- >70% correctly parsed
- >60% end-to-end accuracy
- No regression in symbol detection (96.6% mAP50)

Full context: /home/woodson/.claude/plans/cosmic-mixing-stream.md

Critical constraints (DO NOT CHANGE):
- DPI: 72 training, 150 display, 2.083x scale
- SAHI: 2048px tiles, 0.2 overlap
- Database schema: Already has OCR fields
- UI: Already displays identifier/target_sheet

title: Optimize YOLO for Recall: Lower Confidence & Retrain
description:
## Objective

Improve callout detection recall from 34-44% to 80%+ by optimizing for recall instead of mAP.

## Context

Extended training improved mAP (82.7% ‚Üí 93.0%) but DECREASED production recall:
- Validation set has 89 ground truth callouts on page 1
- Baseline yolo26n: 79 detections (44% recall)
- Improved yolo26n: 67 detections (34% recall)
- yolo26s: 58 detections (26% recall)

**Root Cause:** mAP optimizes precision+recall balance. Extended training increased precision but decreased recall by 23%.

**Solution:** Stop optimizing for mAP. Focus on RECALL.

See: `README_RECALL_OPTIMIZATION.md` for full analysis and commands.

---

## ‚úÖ Step 1 Complete: Lower Confidence Testing

### Results

| Model | Conf | Total | Detail | Elevation | Recall vs 89GT | Change |
|-------|------|-------|--------|-----------|----------------|--------|
| Baseline | 0.10 | 79 | 34 | 45 | 44% | baseline |
| Baseline | 0.05 | 99 | 43 | 56 | 56% | +20 |
| **Baseline** | **0.03** | **117** | **54** | **63** | **66%** | **+38** üèÜ |
| Improved | 0.10 | 67 | 34 | 33 | 34% | baseline |
| Improved | 0.05 | 80 | 44 | 35 | 45% | +13 |
| Improved | 0.03 | 98 | 56 | 40 | 55% | +31 |

### Key Findings

**MAJOR WIN:** Simply lowering confidence threshold from 0.1 to 0.03 increased detections by **48%** without any retraining\!

**Winner:** Baseline yolo26n at conf=0.03
- 117 detections (vs 79 baseline)
- 66% recall (vs 89 ground truth)
- Still 14 percentage points short of 80% target

**Visualization:** `threshold_comparison.png` shows clear inverse relationship between confidence and detections.

---

## ‚úÖ Step 2 Complete: PR Curve Analysis

### Validation vs Production Gap

**Validation Metrics (dataset_highres/valid):**

| Model | Precision | Recall | mAP50 | mAP50-95 |
|-------|-----------|--------|-------|----------|
| Baseline | 81.4% | **73.8%** | 83.1% | 61.9% |
| Improved | 91.8% | **83.5%** | 93.6% | 72.6% |

**Production Metrics (4-Structural-Drawings.pdf):**

| Model | Conf | Detections | Recall vs 89 GT |
|-------|------|------------|-----------------|
| Baseline | 0.10 | 79 | **44%** |
| Baseline | 0.03 | 117 | **66%** |
| Improved | 0.10 | 67 | **34%** |
| Improved | 0.03 | 98 | **55%** |

### Critical Discovery: Validation Set is Misleading

**Gap: 8-28 percentage points lower in production\!**

- Validation shows 73.8-83.5% recall
- Production shows 44-66% recall
- Models aren't as good as validation metrics suggest

**Root Cause:**
- Validation set: 13 images (too small)
- Doesn't represent production complexity
- Training against bad validation won't improve production

---

## Decision: Skip Steps 3-4 (Retraining)

### Why Skip?

1. **Validation set is unreliable** - Training against bad validation won't improve production performance
2. **Already achieved +48% improvement** - conf=0.03 gave major gains without retraining
3. **Better ROI on dataset improvement** - Fixing the dataset will help more than more training
4. **Still 14pp short of target** - Need better approach than just retraining

### What We Learned

‚úÖ Lower confidence thresholds work (Step 1)
‚úÖ Validation-production gap identified (Step 2)
‚ùå Current validation set is not representative
‚ùå More training on bad data won't help (Steps 3-4)

---

## Next Steps (Prioritized)

### 1. Deploy conf=0.03 in Production (IMMEDIATE)
- Update production config to use conf=0.03
- Accept higher false positive rate
- Filter with OCR validation
- **Expected:** 117 detections (66% recall) immediately

### 2. Improve Dataset (HIGH PRIORITY - See sitelink-XXX)
- Collect 50+ diverse production plans (US + Canada)
- Include various drawing types, standards, complexity
- Properly annotate ALL callouts (not just easy ones)
- Create representative train/val/test split
- **Expected:** Models that generalize to production

### 3. Only Then: Retrain for Recall
- Use new, representative validation set
- Monitor recall, not mAP
- Increase objectness loss weight
- Select checkpoint based on recall, not mAP

### 4. Consider Alternative Approaches
- Two-stage detection (high recall YOLO + OCR filter)
- Different architecture (Faster R-CNN for tiny objects)
- Ensemble models
- Higher resolution (4096px)

---

## Files Created

- ‚úÖ `README_RECALL_OPTIMIZATION.md` - Full analysis and testing guide
- ‚úÖ `src/generate_pr_curve.py` - PR curve generation
- ‚úÖ `threshold_comparison.csv` - Threshold test results
- ‚úÖ `threshold_comparison.png` - Visualization
- ‚úÖ `pr_comparison.txt` - PR analysis
- ‚è≠Ô∏è `src/train_for_recall.py` - Recall-focused training (deferred)
- ‚è≠Ô∏è `src/train_highres_4096.py` - High-res training (deferred)

---

## Timeline

- ‚úÖ Step 1: 30 min (testing) - COMPLETE
- ‚úÖ Step 2: 30 min (PR curves) - COMPLETE
- ‚è≠Ô∏è Step 3: Deferred (retraining) - Waiting for better dataset
- ‚è≠Ô∏è Step 4: Deferred (high-res) - Waiting for better dataset

**Total time spent:** 1 hour
**Improvement achieved:** +48% detections (79 ‚Üí 117)
**Cost:** Free (no retraining needed)

---

## Related Beads

- sitelink-p4b: Extended training results (inverse mAP/recall relationship)
- sitelink-uiz: yolo26s vs yolo26n comparison
- sitelink-e1z: 72 DPI rendering decision
- **sitelink-XXX: Dataset improvement plan** (to be created)

title: Fix callout marker positioning: use normalized coordinates
description:
## Problem

Callout markers are not positioned correctly on the plan viewer. They appear offset from the actual callout symbols.

### Root Cause

The container's `detect_callouts_with_llm` function converts LLM-returned normalized coordinates (0-1) to absolute pixel coordinates at 300 DPI before storing them:

```python
# server.py lines 586-587
"x": int(rel_x * width) if rel_x <= 1 else int(rel_x),
"y": int(rel_y * height) if rel_y <= 1 else int(rel_y),
```

But the viewer uses these pixel coordinates directly without accounting for the actual displayed image size, which may differ from the 300 DPI detection size.

### Correct Approach (from backend-dev demo)

The demo stored **normalized (0-1) coordinates** and multiplied by actual tile image size at render time:

```javascript
const imageSize = tiledImage.getContentSize();
const tilePixelX = h.x * imageSize.x;  // h.x is 0-1 normalized
const tilePixelY = h.y * imageSize.y;
```

## Solution

Store normalized coordinates (0-1) in events instead of converting to pixels. Update all viewers to scale at render time.

## Implementation Plan

### Step 1: Update Container (server.py)

File: `apps/backend/container/server.py`

In `detect_callouts_with_llm` function (~line 576-590):

**Before:**
```python
processed_markers.append({
    "id": f"marker-{sheet_id}-{i}-{uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]}",
    "label": marker.get('label', ''),
    "targetSheetRef": marker.get('targetSheetRef'),
    "x": int(rel_x * width) if rel_x <= 1 else int(rel_x),
    "y": int(rel_y * height) if rel_y <= 1 else int(rel_y),
    "confidence": marker.get('confidence', 0.5),
    "needsReview": marker.get('needsReview', False)
})
```

**After:**
```python
processed_markers.append({
    "id": f"marker-{sheet_id}-{i}-{uuid.uuid4().hex[:8]}",
    "label": marker.get('label', ''),
    "targetSheetRef": marker.get('targetSheetRef'),
    "x": float(rel_x) if rel_x <= 1 else float(rel_x / width),  # Keep normalized 0-1
    "y": float(rel_y) if rel_y <= 1 else float(rel_y / height), # Keep normalized 0-1
    "confidence": marker.get('confidence', 0.5),
    "needsReview": marker.get('needsReview', False)
})
```

Also update CV fallback (~line 660-670) to return normalized coords:
```python
height, width = img.shape[:2]  # Get dimensions
# ...
markers.append({
    "x": float(x) / width,   # Normalize
    "y": float(y) / height,  # Normalize
    # ...
})
```

### Step 2: Update Event Schema Documentation

File: `packages/domain/src/events.ts`

Add JSDoc comment to clarify coordinate system:

```typescript
// In sheetCalloutsDetected and sheetCalloutsUpdated schemas:
x: Schema.Number,  // Normalized coordinate (0-1), multiply by image width to get pixels
y: Schema.Number,  // Normalized coordinate (0-1), multiply by image height to get pixels
```

### Step 3: Update Backend Viewer

File: `apps/backend/viewer/src/components/PMTilesViewer.tsx`

In `addMarkerOverlays` callback (~line 26-70):

**Before:**
```typescript
const imageRect = new OpenSeadragon.Rect(
  marker.x - overlayPixelSize / 2,
  marker.y - overlayPixelSize / 2,
  overlayPixelSize,
  overlayPixelSize
)
```

**After:**
```typescript
const tiledImage = viewer.world.getItemAt(0)
const imageSize = tiledImage.getContentSize()

// Convert normalized (0-1) to tile pixel coordinates
const tilePixelX = marker.x * imageSize.x
const tilePixelY = marker.y * imageSize.y

  tilePixelX - overlayPixelSize / 2,
  tilePixelY - overlayPixelSize / 2,
  overlayPixelSize,
  overlayPixelSize
)
```

File: `apps/mobile/components/plans/viewer/openseadragon-viewer.tsx` (or similar)

### Step 5: Migration Consideration

**Important**: Existing marker data in the database uses pixel coordinates. Options:

A) **Re-process existing plans** - Trigger callout detection again for existing sheets
B) **Handle both formats** - Check if x/y > 1, treat as legacy pixel coords and normalize using sheet dimensions
C) **Clear and restart** - If in dev, clear existing data and re-upload PDFs

Recommended: Option B for backwards compatibility:

```typescript
// In viewer, handle both formats:
const isNormalized = marker.x <= 1 && marker.y <= 1
const tilePixelX = isNormalized 
  ? marker.x * imageSize.x 
  : (marker.x / sheetWidth) * imageSize.x  // Legacy: normalize then scale
const tilePixelY = isNormalized
  ? marker.y * imageSize.y
  : (marker.y / sheetHeight) * imageSize.y
```

### Why This Architecture

1. **All network in React Native** - Avoids CORS, auth, and Android cleartext issues
2. **PMTiles in RN, not WebView** - PMTiles library extracts tiles, RN converts to base64
3. **Native Actions Pattern** - imageLoader.addJob override with native-bridge:// protocol
4. **Single file sync** - PMTiles is one file vs thousands of tile images
5. **Progressive loading** - User sees plan immediately, better experience comes later

## Local Metadata Schema (Expo SQLite)

| Column       | Type | Description                                    |
|--------------|------|------------------------------------------------|
| id           | TEXT | Plan ID (UUID)                                 |
| sync_status  | INT  | 0: Remote Only, 1: Syncing, 2: Ready Offline   |
| local_uri    | TEXT | Path to .pmtiles in FileSystem.documentDirectory |
| fallback_url | TEXT | Public R2 URL for original high-res JPEG       |
| width        | INT  | Image width in pixels                          |
| height       | INT  | Image height in pixels                         |
| min_zoom     | INT  | Minimum zoom level in PMTiles                  |
| max_zoom     | INT  | Maximum zoom level in PMTiles                  |

## Coordinate System Notes

From docs/openseadragon/old_docs-1.md:
- Detection uses normalized coords (0-1)
- Multiply by actual tile dimensions: tilePixelX = normalized.x * imageSize.x
- Use imageToViewportRectangle() for overlay positioning
- Use MouseTracker for click handling (not vanilla JS events)

## Storage & Performance Rules

- **Target PMTiles size**: < 50MB per plan
- **WebP quality**: Q=75 (if > 50MB, reduce to Q=65)
- **Resolution**: 300 DPI (industry standard for blueprints)
- **R2 CORS**: Must expose Content-Length and Content-Range headers
- **imageLoaderLimit**: 2 (prevent overwhelming RN bridge)

## Related Documentation
- docs/openseadragon/old_docs-1.md - Coordinate system handling
- docs/openseadragon/old_docs-2.md - Native Actions pattern for tile loading
- docs/openseadragon/static-image-implementation.md - Static image fallback
notes:
## One-Pass Pipeline Update

Simplified the VIPS pipeline to eliminate intermediate PNG step:

**Old (two-pass):**
```bash
vips copy "plan.pdf[dpi=300]" plan.png
vips dzsave plan.png tmp_tiles --layout google --suffix ".webp[Q=75]"
```

**New (one-pass):**
```bash
vips dzsave "plan.pdf[dpi=300]" tmp_tiles --layout google --suffix ".webp[Q=75]"
```

Benefits:
- No intermediate file (saves disk I/O)
- Faster (single operation)
- Less memory usage

The [dpi=300] bracket syntax tells VIPS to render PDF at 300 DPI during load.

## Maestro Test
```yaml
appId: com.sitelink.app
---
- launchApp
- tapOn: "Camera"
- assertVisible:
    id: "camera-viewfinder"
- assertVisible:
    id: "flash-toggle"
- assertVisible:
    id: "camera-flip"
- tapOn:
    id: "flash-toggle"
# Flash icon should change
```

## Implementation
```typescript
import { CameraView, useCameraPermissions } from 'expo-camera'

function CameraScreen() {
  const [permission, requestPermission] = useCameraPermissions()
  const [facing, setFacing] = useState<'front' | 'back'>('back')
  const [flash, setFlash] = useState<'off' | 'on' | 'auto'>('off')
  const cameraRef = useRef<CameraView>(null)
  
  if (!permission?.granted) {
    return <PermissionRequest onRequest={requestPermission} />
  }
  
  return (
    <View style={{ flex: 1 }}>
      <CameraView
        ref={cameraRef}
        testID="camera-viewfinder"
        style={{ flex: 1 }}
        facing={facing}
        flash={flash}
      />
      <View style={styles.controls}>
        <IconButton
          testID="flash-toggle"
          icon={flashIcon[flash]}
          onPress={() => setFlash(cycleFlash(flash))}
        />
        <IconButton
          testID="camera-flip"
          icon="camera-flip"
          onPress={() => setFacing(f => f === 'back' ? 'front' : 'back')}
        />
      </View>
    </View>
  )
}
```

title: YOLO training/inference scale mismatch causes poor detection
description:
## Problem
Training images from Roboflow are 2048x1536 showing the ENTIRE page, so callout symbols are ~30-50px.

At 300 DPI inference, the PDF renders to 14,400x10,800 and gets tiled to 2048x2048 chunks. Each tile shows only 1/50th of the page, so callouts shrink to ~5-10px - too small for the model to recognize.

## Evidence
- At 300 DPI: Model detects almost nothing (11 detections)
- At 72 DPI: Model detects actual callout symbols (34 detections)
- Training annotations ARE correct (verified visually)

## Root Cause
The 300 DPI was chosen for CV-based circle detection which needed high resolution. But YOLO training data is at ~72 DPI equivalent (full page in 2048px).

## Options
1. Train on 300 DPI tiles (match inference)
2. Use 72 DPI inference (lower quality, but works)
3. Use multi-scale training augmentation
notes: **Decision**: Use 72 DPI inference (no tiling needed). Full page at 72 DPI is ~3400x2600px which matches training scale. The 300 DPI was from original CV-based approach. Future: Could train on 300 DPI tiles using Google Colab (requires re-annotation on tiles).

title: Implement LiveStore sync backend with Durable Objects
description:
## Overview
Cloudflare Durable Objects backend for syncing LiveStore events across devices. Handles WebSocket connections, event persistence, and conflict resolution.

## Agent Assignment
@agent-backend

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] WebSocket endpoint for real-time sync connections
- [ ] Durable Object per organization for event isolation
- [ ] Events persisted to DO SQLite storage
- [ ] Conflict resolution follows LiveStore CRDT merge strategy
- [ ] Sync works correctly across multiple devices
- [ ] Offline events queue locally and sync on reconnection
- [ ] Auth token validated on WebSocket connection
- [ ] Event batching for efficient sync (max 100 events/batch)
- [ ] Heartbeat mechanism for connection health
- [ ] Graceful reconnection handling

## Example Sync Flow
```
Device A (offline):
1. User captures photo
2. photoCaptured event committed to local LiveStore
3. Event persisted to local SQLite
4. UI updates immediately
5. Event queued for sync

Device A (comes online):
1. WebSocket connects to /sync/{orgId}
2. Auth token validated
3. Queued events pushed to Durable Object
4. DO persists events, broadcasts to other connections
5. Acknowledgment sent back

Device B (online):
1. Receives photoCaptured event via WebSocket
2. Event applied to local LiveStore
3. Materializer updates photos table
4. UI reactively updates
```

## API Specification
```
WebSocket: wss://api.sitelink.app/sync/{orgId}

Connection:
- Header: Authorization: Bearer {token}
- On connect: Send { type: 'init', lastEventId: 'xxx' }
- Server responds: { type: 'sync', events: [...] }

Messages:
- Client ‚Üí Server: { type: 'events', events: [...] }
- Server ‚Üí Client: { type: 'events', events: [...] }
- Server ‚Üí Client: { type: 'ack', eventIds: [...] }
- Ping/Pong for keepalive
```

## Design Notes
- Use @livestore/sync-server-cloudflare package
- One Durable Object per organization
- DO SQLite stores event log
- WebSocket handler in Worker routes to DO
- Consider DO hibernation for cost optimization
- Rate limit: 1000 events/minute per connection

## Summary
Implemented high-resolution image support for Gemini Flash 2 text extraction to reduce hallucinations when reading callout symbols.

## Problem
Gemini was hallucinating incorrect numbers when reading detail/elevation callouts (e.g., reading "14/S4.1" instead of "2/S4.1"). This was caused by:
1. Low resolution crops (72 DPI) making text hard to read
2. Padding around crops including surrounding plan text that confused the model

## Solution
1. **High-res crops**: Added `--hires-image` flag to api_detect.py
   - YOLO detection runs on 72 DPI (model requirement)
   - Bounding boxes scaled to 150 DPI coordinates
   - Crops taken from original 150 DPI image (2x larger text)

2. **Tight bbox crops**: Removed padding (was 1.5x expansion)
   - Crops now exactly match YOLO bounding box
   - Eliminates surrounding text that confused Gemini

3. **Sheet info extraction**: New batch extraction for sheet number + title
   - extract_sheet_info_gemini.py for batched API calls
   - 10 pages per batch for efficiency
   - UI now displays sheet_title in sidebar

Construction plan callouts are CIRCULAR BUBBLES containing:

- Dividing line

**Winner: Circle Detection using Hough Transform**
- Detects circular callout bubbles
- Applies circular mask to OCR only text inside
- Parses two-line format correctly

title: yolo26n Extended Training Results: Higher mAP but Lower Recall
description:
## Training Results

**Extended Training:**
- Epochs: 200 (patience 50)
- Best epoch: 198
- Best mAP50: 93.0% (vs 82.7% baseline)
- Improvement: +10.3 percentage points

## Detection Performance Comparison

**Test on 4-Structural-Drawings.pdf:**

| Model | mAP50 | Total Detections | Detail | Elevation | Recall Rank |
|-------|-------|-----------------|--------|-----------|-------------|
| **Baseline yolo26n** | 82.7% | **79** | 34 | 45 | ü•á BEST |
| **Improved yolo26n** | 93.0% | **67** | 34 | 33 (-12) | ü•à Middle |
| **yolo26s** | 96.5% | **58-60** | - | - | ü•â Worst |

## Critical Finding: Inverse Relationship

**Higher validation mAP = Lower production recall**

This pattern holds across all three models:
- yolo26s (96.5% mAP) ‚Üí 58 detections
- Improved yolo26n (93.0% mAP) ‚Üí 67 detections  
- Baseline yolo26n (82.7% mAP) ‚Üí 79 detections

## Analysis

Despite achieving much higher mAP on validation set, the improved model detects FEWER callouts on real plans:

1. **Higher precision, lower recall** - Model is more conservative
2. **OCR validation failures** - Many detections rejected due to '$2.0' vs 'S2.0' OCR errors (110 raw detections ‚Üí 30 validated on sheet 1)
3. **Validation set doesn't represent real-world plans** - Optimizing for validation mAP makes models more conservative

## Conclusion

Extended training improved validation metrics but made the model MORE conservative in production. All three models show the same pattern: **the validation set is misleading**.

The **baseline yolo26n (82.7% mAP)** remains the best choice for production use despite having the lowest validation mAP.

## Next Steps

1. Investigate why validation set is misleading (composition, diversity, difficulty)
2. Test models at lower confidence thresholds
3. Review OCR validation logic (why '$' instead of 'S'?)
4. Consider creating a more representative validation set from real production plans

## RECALL DROP ANALYSIS - ITERATION 1

### Current Situation

**Training from scratch at Epoch 88/150:**
- Precision: 89.6% (up from 96.8% baseline)
- Recall: 60.8% (DOWN from 75.3% baseline) ‚ö†Ô∏è

**This is the EXACT same problem as described in this ticket.**

### Root Cause

Training **from scratch** makes the model too conservative:
- Learns to only predict when VERY confident
- Results in higher precision (fewer false positives)
- But lower recall (misses more callouts)

### Solution: Fine-Tuning Instead of Training From Scratch

**If recall doesn't improve to >70% by epoch 150, switch to fine-tuning:**

```bash

# Reduce epochs since starting from trained weights

```

**Expected results with fine-tuning:**
- Start with 75.3% recall (preserve baseline)
- Improve to 80-85% recall with more data
- Maintain precision >90%

### Alternative: Adjust Training Hyperparameters

If still training from scratch, try:
- Lower confidence threshold (0.15 instead of 0.25)
- Increase recall weight in loss function
- Add more hard negative mining

```yaml
appId: com.sitelink.app

- tapOn: "Notifications"
```
